title: Outrage as Chinese firm gets green light to run UK railway but they promise Wi-Fi and more seats

organizations.name: first mtr south western trains limited

text:
Chinese firm MTR have pledged to create 22,000 more seats to Waterloo, as well as free Wi-Fi at stations (Photo: Wikipedia) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A Chinese firm has been brought in by the government to run one of the biggest rail franchises in the country. 
The surprise move will see Hong Kong Metro operator MTR run South West Trains (SWT) with the giant First Group for seven years from August. 
Transport Secretary Chris Grayling announced the decision in a bid to boost punctuality and reliability. 
He said: "MTR run one of the world’s busiest metro services in Hong Kong, on which 99.9 per cent of journeys run on time. 
"The new operator will bring about a transformation for people travelling in and around London." 
First MTR will take over from Stagecoach , which currently runs SWT services across south east England to and from London Waterloo. 
But the Rail, Maritime and Transport (RMT) union said the Chinese state was now set to make "a killing at the British taxpayers’ expense." 
The RMT said the move intensified foreign ownership of Britain’s railways. Read More Last chance to claim Southern compensation if you've been affected by strikes in 2016 - how to get your money back Chris Grayling says the move will help the rail service run faster (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Of the 28 private rail contracts 21 or 75% are partially or wholly owned by foreign states or their railways. 
Mick Cash, RMT general secretary, said: "That is nothing short of a scandal and reinforces the demand for nationalisation of our rail assets for the benefit of the British passenger and taxpayer." 
And Manuel Cortes, leader of the TSSA rail union, said: "However they want to spin it, this government’s experiment with rail franchises is a busted flush. 
"They don’t deliver better services, they deliver higher fares for passengers who are milked as cash cows by the franchisee." 
The Department for Transport (DfT) said: "First MTR South Western Trains Limited will use the experience of one of its major shareholders MTR, who operate the busy Hong Kong metro, to deliver smooth and rapid journeys for passengers travelling around London’s suburban network. 
"Faster journeys will be delivered through a consistent fleet of new suburban trains offering a regular, metro-style service. Passengers can look forward to more space." Read More Next stop, the kitchen... Astonishing pictures show Chinese train that goes THROUGH a block of flats MTR's metro service in Hong Kong has a 99 per cent punctuality record (Photo: Wikipedia) 
Mr Grayling added: "First MTR South Western Trains Limited will deliver the improvements that people tell us they want right across the South Western franchise area, from Bristol and Exeter, to Southampton and Portsmouth, to Reading, Windsor and London. 
"We are delivering the biggest rail modernisation programme for over a century and this franchise will deliver real changes for passengers, who can look forward to modern trains, faster journeys and a more reliable service." 
First MTR South Western Trains also pledged a £1.2 billion investment for the seven-year franchise to deliver a range of improvements including: 
- 22,000 extra seats into London Waterloo each morning peak and 30,000 extra seats out of Waterloo each evening peak. 
- 90 new trains, providing more space for passengers on Reading, Windsor and London routes. 
- Flexible season tickets, offering a discount for passengers travelling fewer than five days a week. 
- At least 1,500 new car park spaces. 
- New Delay Repay compensation, including for delays of 15 minutes or more, and with automatic claims for smart card season tickets and advance purchased tickets bought in advance through digital channels. 
- Free Wi-Fi at all stations and on many trains. Read More Good news for thousands of commuters as Southern Railway on brink of deal with train unions MTR will take over running of South West trains in August (Photo: Wikipedia) 
MTR, which is owned by the Hong Kong government, runs rail services between London Liverpool Street and Shenfield. 
It will operate the new Crossrail line through London from the end of next year. 
It jointly ran London Overground with Arriva until last December and has rail operations around the world including China, Sweden and Australia. 
SWT commuter lines are the busiest in Europe, with passenger numbers doubling since it became the first rail company to be privatised 21 years ago. 
Every year 100 million people travel to and from London’s Waterloo - the busiest station in the country. 
SWT runs 1,700 trains a day serving 200 stations and employs 4,500 staff. 
The punctuality level on this South Western franchise was 88.2 per cent, below the national average, and the new operator will have to increase it to 91.1 per cent by 2017/18. Foreign operators on British railways 
Arriva, a subsidiary of German state-owned Deutsche Bahn, which is involved in Chiltern, Cross Country, Grand Central, London Overground, Northern, Tyne & Wear Metro and Wales & Borders. 
French state-controlled Keolis is involved in Docklands Light Railway, Gatwick Express, London Midland, Southern, South Eastern and Thameslink. 
Abellio, the international arm of the Dutch national rail operator, is involved in Scotrail, Greater Anglia and Merseyrail. 
Eurostar is part-owned by the French and Belgian state rail operators. 
Heathrow Express and Heathrow Connect are owned by Heathrow Airport Holdings, a consortium 41.8% of which is owned by the sovereign wealth funds of Singapore, China and Qatar. Like us on Facebook
